thread.title: Brexit vote six months on: What's happening with Article 50 and when can we expect to leave?
thread.title_full: Brexit vote six months on: What's happening with Article 50 and when can we expect to leave?

author: Sean Seddon
title: Brexit vote six months on: What's happening with Article 50 and when can we expect to leave?
text:
A man waves the EU flag in front of the Supreme Court (Photo: Getty Images Europe) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
At times, the Brexit process can seem complex and strange - because it is. 
What we didn’t know when we voted on June 23 was that we were also bringing a whole load of new jargon into the English language. 
Do you want your Brexit served hard or soft? 
Have you read your 50 articles a day on Article 50? 
Are we having a cliff-edge Brexit or a...non-cliff-edge Brexit? 
Here’s everything you need to know so far and what you can expect in 2017 and beyond. Let’s start at the beginning. This Article 50 business - what actually is it? 
Article 50 is a niche, untested clause buried at the bottom of the Treaty of Lisbon. 
Clocking in at fewer than 300 words, Article 50 is about as short and vague a legal document as you’re ever likely to see - and that’s a problem. 
There isn’t a template for leaving the EU . 
No plan, no method, no handy diagram telling you what to do and how to do it. 
You have to agree to leave, tell the EU you’re going, negotiate a deal - oh, and you’ve got two years to do it. 
And that’s it. 
The Article 50 process is what we’re about to embark on: putting this piece of legal theory to the test. Nigel Farage (Photo: Yui Mok/PA Wire) I’ve heard people talking about “notification” - what’s that all about? 
Notifying the EU of our intention to leave is the point at which that two year stop clock starts. 
It’s the point at which the process of leaving the EU actually begins. 
The government has announced that they will do this no later than the end of March 2017. 
This is a political promise - technically, the government could trigger Article 50 in March 3017 if it wanted to. 
But, as it currently stands, the two-year window to re-arrange our relationship with the EU will begin in the next three months or so. 
And remember: during these two years we will continue to be full, paid-up members of the EU - although we’ll have no say on how it is run or how the money is spent. So that means we’ll be out of the EU by April 2019? 
Pretty much. 
That certainly doesn’t mean everything will be wrapped up and ticketyboo by then but we will officially be “out of Europe” by April 2019. But two years is loads of time to sort everything out, right? 
That sound you just heard was 100 government lawyers choking on their mulled wine. 
There is an incredible amount of technical details to sort out. 
And we’re not particularly well prepared for it - for example, the Civil Service is currently hiring trade negotiators because we haven’t needed or trained any since we joined the European Economic Community in 1973. Prime Minister Theresa May (Photo: PA) Well, what sort of detail? 
To begin with, there is the small matter of renegotiating how we buy and sell with the world’s largest free trade bloc. 
We need to agree on what happens to EU citizens already living in the UK and UK citizens already living in the EU. 
We need to figure out how we’re going to trade with other countries around the world because the EU has done that on our behalf for forty years. 
We need new security processes, new environmental arrangements, new laws, new regulations. 
Every contract drawn up under EU law will need to be reviewed, every joint foreign policy action taken with the EU will need to be reconsidered. 
Oh, and on top of all that, there’s the small business of running the UK’s schools, hospitals, roads, prisons, tax system, courts, economy and everything else that the government has to do on a daily basis. 
It would be nothing short of a miracle if that was all done in two years. Right...so what if it isn’t all done by April 2019? 
The government have pretty much accepted that this is likely so talk has turned to a “transitional” deal. 
In this scenario, the UK would formally leave the EU by 2019 but the trickiest negotiations would continue beyond then. 
For example, complex talks over finance could run beyond the April 2019 deadline if both parties agree to retain the current arrangements or something similar for a few years longer. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
